sect1.title: Introduction
Types
sect1.para:
There aren't different types of transactional refs. Some are optimized for primitive types, while the 'Ref' is optimized for object references:
IntRef: a transactional ref for primitive int.
BooleanRef: a transactional refs for the primitive boolean.
LongRef: a transactional ref for the primitive long.
DoubleRef: a transactional ref for the primitive double.
Ref: a transactional ref for storing a object reference.
The advantage of the primitive types is that they not only have methods only useful for their specific type (like increment) but also that they prevent unwanted autoboxing. Generating millions of objects per second, just kills performance and scalability.

sect1.title: Atomic methods
sect1.para: The different ref implementation also expose atomic methods like atomicGet/atomicSet (and many more). These methods automatically run under their own 'txn' and ignoring the current txn if one is available. Atomic methods are very fast since a lot of overhead of the txn is removed.

sect1.title: Commute
sect1.para: It is important to realize that although certain operations commute, e.g. the add or multiply, but they don't have to commute with each other. So be careful when combining different commuting operations.
